is a city in the province

. It is a typical Dutch city with many old buildings, canals and pretty sights, and is a popular destination for a day trip. It is also a good base for exploring the rest of the Netherlands, thanks to its great rail- and highway connections. The city is famous for its cheese, its 15th century town hall and the amazing glass windows in St. Janskerk, but there is a lot more to see and do.

value: View over one of the city's canals

Gouda has a population of just over 70,000. As well as its cheese, Gouda is also famous for its stroopwafels (syrup waffles), candles and its clay pipes. Most of the city is below sea level, and the lowest point of the Netherlands can be found a few kilometers outside the city.

Gouda is pronounced

-da, with the 'g' pronounced similarly to the 'ch' in 'loch', not with a hard 'g' like how native English speakers pronounce the name of the cheese. Saying the name correctly will win you points with the locals!

Gouda is named after the river Gouwe and the Van der Goude family, who built a castle on the Gouwe River in the 11th century. At that time, the area was swampland. Over the next two hundred years peat was collected and the land was developed. In 1225, a canal was built connecting the Gouwe River with the Oude Rijn (part of the Rhine delta). This was used to help ship goods to France and further afield. This provided a safer route than traveling by sea. This resulted in a surge of economic activity around Gouda and the town gained importance. In 1272, it was declared a city. Most of the canals were built around this time.

Over the years, there have been fires (1361, 1438), occupations (1572) and plagues (1574, 1625, 1636, 1673). In 1577, the castle was destroyed. Despite these disasters, Gouda is still a beautiful place to visit.

In 1667 a tax was introduced on the locally produced cheese. This raised a lot of money for the town. In 1668, the Waag (cheese weighing house) was built, to weigh the cheese and collect this tax.
There are two train stations in Gouda - Gouda (the main station, 5mins walk to the Markt) and Gouda Goverwelle (in suburbia). For the timetable check

(in English). 

Trains have been running between Gouda and Utrecht since 1855; in 1944 the old train station was damaged by Allied bombing.

There are five ways to travel to Gouda by train.

value: - takes less than 20 minutes. Take a train in the direction of
- takes less than 20 minutes. Take a train towards
. Gouda is right in the middle of these train lines. Eight trains an hour.
- takes 40–60 minutes. There is one slow direct train an hour. It is also possible to take the intercity train to Utrecht and transfer there, which takes about the same time.
and from there you can take a train to Gouda. Before and after working hours, there are direct trains running from Leiden to Gouda.

When you arrive at the train station, take the exit called "Centrumzijde" or just "Centrum". There should be a sign pointing you to the city centre. If you can't find it, just go the way most people go and you will be in the city centre very soon.

If you want to take a taxi, there will most likely be drivers waiting for customers. They will pick up you up on the street outside the station. If there aren't any taxis around, you can call them.
Buses stop at the train station. Most of them are operated by

.

There are buses connecting Gouda with

and some more towns.

Buses are slower and more expensive than trains. If you have the option, choose the train.
Gouda is directly located on the A12 and A20.

value: - about 20 mins. Take the A12 towards Utrecht
- about 15mins. Take the A20 towards Utrecht.
). Or (slightly longer, but without leaving the motorway), take the A4 to
and then the A12 to Gouda.

Parking is cheapest in one of the large parking lots just outside the city center (about €1,40-1,60 an hour). These are well indicated. There are two public garages in the city center, called Bolwerk and Nieuwe Markt. These are located closer to the interesting part of the city, but are also a bit more expensive (about €12 a day). It is not advised to park on the streets because that's really expensive.

There are no ferry or waterbus services to Gouda, but when you own a boat, there are facilities to stay in Gouda. The local port authority has published an information leaflet in English, German and Dutch. It can be found

The city centre of Gouda is surrounded by a circular canal. The city only started to expand beyond this circle in the late 19th century, so most historic sights can be found within it. It is also the main shopping district of the city.
The centre of Gouda is small and very easy to walk around. A lot of the street are pedestrianized. The main shopping street,
, is pedestrianized and bike free. At the centre of Gouda and the end of Kleiweg is the central square of the city, called
are here, and this is where the weekly

If you want to travel outside the centre of Gouda, biking is a good option. At the tourist office, staff can tell you the most interesting routes to cycle, both within the city as well as the immediate surroundings (
). Most of the streets in the centre are bike friendly, the main exception being

. You can walk along this street with your bike, just don't cycle. As you would expect in a Dutch city, there are lots of bicycle parking opportunities. Make sure you lock it. Bike theft is very common in the Netherlands.

Bikes can be rented from:

The area surrounding the St. Janskerk is worth a visit

Gouda is a typical and beautiful Dutch town. It's a great place to wander, checking out the old buildings and the quiet canals.

value: hours=Summer - opened every day from 10:00-17:00. On Thursday from 10:00-21:00
content=The old Townhall on the market square is the oldest Gothic town hall in The Netherlands. Built out of natural materials between 1448 and 1450, it is now a museum.
name=The Cheese Market and De Waag

hours=Every Thursday morning in the summer, there is a traditional cheese market. The building where the cheese used to be weighed (De Waag) is a typical example of neoclassical Dutch architecture from the 17th century and now hosts a small cheese museum. De Waag is opened 1 Apr-31 Oct, Tu-Su: 1PM-5PM, Th 10AM-5PM
content=Check out the cheese market, eat some cheese, see the old cheese weighing house, built by Pieter Post in 1668, now a museum to (you guessed it) cheese!

content=This church is famous for its beautiful stained glass windows and is a must see. It is the longest church in the Netherlands (longest, not the tallest!). The area around the church is the oldest and probably the most beautiful part of town.
directions=Entrance located next to the St. Janskerk. Pass through the small gate.

content=This museum traces the history of Gouda. There are displays of paintings, archaeology, old clay pipes and pottery. Information and guided tours are available in English. Recently, a massive scale model of the city center in the 16th century was added to the collection.
content=This museum tracks the history of Gouda harbour and shipbuilding. There are also some old ships and buildings to see. All the information is in Dutch.
content=The history of the Dutch resistance in World War II. Article info and guided tours available in English.
content=One of the oldest remaining brick houses in Gouda. Listed by UNESCO as one of the top 100 listed building in the Netherlands.
content=There are various canals in the city center. They are lined by historic houses. A visit to Gouda is not complete without taking a relaxing walk along the canals!
content=This canal is actually an old river, the one that gave Gouda its name. The canal is dominated by the 80-metre tower of the Gouwekerk (Gouwe church)
content=One side of the canal is called Oosthaven, the other is called Westhaven. The buildings along this canal were built by the patriarchy of the city in the 17th and 18th century.
content=The quays of this canal are extremely low. It is lined by interesting historic buildings.
content=Charming little canal lined by old warehouses that were converted to houses.
content=There are four windmills (two of them in the city centre) remaining in Gouda.
content=Possible to visit by appointment only.
content=In the 1970's, this graveyard was abandoned, but the graves are still there, covered in tall grass. It's a little bit eerie, but also a very beautiful place to be.
content=Small 4 screen cinema in centre. English movies shown with Dutch subtitles. Little shop sells snacks and beer.
content=Large theatre (1045 seats) with a diverse line-up.
name=Take a guided tour through the city center
price=€3,50 per person for a tour in a group, €75,- for a private tour.
offers a wide variety of walking tours through the historic city center of Gouda. They can show you the highlights of the city, or will base the tour on a certain historical topic, it's up to you!
content=There are not as many canal boats as in Amsterdam, but it's still possible to take a canal tour through Gouda. Tickets can be bought at the Tourist Office.
content=An old public bathing house from the 1920's has been converted to a lush oriental spa, offering various massages, baths, saunas and beauty treatments.
content=Nine hole golf course, driving range, 18 hole putting green and restaurant. Equipment rental and lessons available.
content=Play snooker, pool or darts. You can also get lessons. There is a bar too.
content=Gallery exhibitions of modern Jewels made by Dutch Jewel-designers. The gallery is open from Thursday till Sunday from 12-17 hrs.
content=Every Thursday between April and August, you can visit the traditional cheese market where farmers sell their cheese. It is located on the Markt square.
content=In the month of December, the city centre gets lit up in special ways. This also contains the Candlelight night on the second Tuesday of December.
content=During the summer season, there are open-air concerts at the Houtmansplantsoen (a park in the city center).
content=An annual event which revolves around food: Culinary Gouda. In September, Houtmansplantsoen in Gouda is transformed into the biggest and tastiest open-air restaurant for miles around.
content=The night before Kingsday, a large open-air music event is hosted on the Markt square. This is usually on april 26th.
content=April 27th is the national holiday of the Netherlands. This is also celebrated in Gouda, with different activities and events each year.

Most shops are open M-Sa 9AM-5PM, and until later on Thursday evenings. On Sundays, many stores are closed, except stores that sell fresh products. Most restaurants and bars are open on Sundays.

The busiest shopping street is Kleiweg. Here you can find the regular brands you can find in many Dutch cities, such as Hema, V&D, H&M, The Sting, Blokker, et cetera. In streets such as Tiendeweg, Zeugstraat and Lange Groenendaal, you can find small independent shops with more unique products.

value: content=This world famous cheese gets its name from the town. It's been made locally with cow's milk since the middle ages. The cheese isn't made in the town itself, but the surrounding area. Real Gouda cheese is made on the farms, and is not pasteurized so it retains much more flavour. As a result of this, the cheese is not exported and can only be bought in the Netherlands. Check out the Cheese market or some of the amazing cheese shops in the town. There are several cheese shops in Gouda
content=Sells Gouda cheese, other cheeses, wine, sauces, etc.
content= Sells cheese, poultry and eggs
content=These traditional Dutch cookies were invented in Gouda in the 19th century. Two thin wafers with a caramel filling. Yummy! You can buy tins and packs of waffles in various shops around town.
directions=On the outside of a hideous building with red tiles
content= For a warm, fresh waffle, try 'Het Stroopwafelwinkeltje', hidden next to the Hema entrance at the Agnietenstraat, just north of the Markt and the Waag.
content= The De Vlaam bakery bought the original stroopwafel recipe when the descendants of the inventor retired.
content=Traditional Dutch candles that light up the room.

content=A traditional grand cafe, located in an old Dutch building with art deco interior at the Markt square. Open throughout the day, with good food and drinks, friendly staff and plenty of space. Renowned for its apple pie.

directions=Down a little lane, just off the Markt.
content=A great cozy Dutch feeling restaurant with great food (especially steaks). The menu is written on a blackboard on the wall. Very popular.

content="In de Salon" is the oldest and one of the best pancake restaurants in Holland, the decor hasn't been changed in 150 years which gives it a very homely old fashioned feel, their pancake's however are made from the freshest ingredients and the poffertjes are baked on their 150 year old wood fired stove, a can't miss when going to Gouda
content=Mexican restaurant running for 18 years in Gouda.
Most bars and restaurants can be found at the Markt
content=A nice and friendly place with a stage and a bar in the centre of Gouda. Perfect to get a drink and go dancing during the weekends. National bands are playing regularly.
hours=Thursdays, Fridays, Saturdays and Sunday, depending on the program

Gouda is a very popular day trip destination. Accommodation options used to be limited, but this has been changing recently.

directions=6km outsude Gouda, just off the A12. Take bus 178 from Gouda.

Gouda is, in general, a safe city, even at night time.
There used to be a lot of car crime, but CCTV cameras have reduced this to normal levels. Just don't leave your valuables in the car.
Due to its central location, Gouda makes for a good base to explore the region and easily connects to other sights in the Netherlands.

value: - this village is 15 km from Gouda, and the route in between makes for a scenic bike ride. Oudewater is famous for its witch weighing house, where they issue certificates proving people aren't witches. It became famous during the 16th century because people accused of witchcraft were offered an honest chance of proving their innocence. In many cities and countries such trials were usually rigged, resulting in the burning or drowning of hundreds of innocent people. No witches ever were found in Oudewater...
- the second largest city in the Netherlands, and the second largest port in the world is only 15mins from Gouda. Check out its 20th century architecture and great shopping.
- home of the Dutch government and the residence of the Dutch Queen, this city is full of history at less than half an hour from Gouda.
- the city has some great historic architecture and is a transport hub for the Netherlands.
- a historic city known for its Delftware pottery, Delft is about 40 mins away (by train or car) from Gouda.
- with the second-largest city centre (after Amsterdam) and a lively student population, Leiden is an interesting city to visit.
